articles.headline: Market Forces Pushing Doctors to Be More Available
articles.snippet: Professional societies for family doctors and internists are urging their members to break with tradition by making it easier to schedule appointments.
articles.abstract: Professional societies for family doctors and internists are urging their members to break with tradition by making it easier to schedule appointments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alice Kissell, 58, a longtime asthma patient, still gets indignant when she recalls the brusque receptionists and hours of waiting to see a doctor at her former health maintenance organization in Southern California.

articles.headline: Fear Invades a Once-Comfortable Iraqi Enclave
articles.snippet: Residents of a Baghdad neighborhood worry that a wave of violence will begin to encroach on them.
articles.abstract: Residents of a Baghdad neighborhood worry that a wave of violence will begin to encroach on them.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 23 — Mansour is Baghdad's Upper East Side. It has fancy pastry shops, jewelry stores, a designer furniture boutique and an elite social club.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Killed Plot in Talking Stage, a Top Aide Says
articles.snippet: A plot to topple the Sears Tower in Chicago was "more aspirational than operational," an official said.
articles.abstract: A plot to topple the Sears Tower in Chicago was "more aspirational than operational," an official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23  A plot to topple the Sears Tower in Chicago and attack the F.B.I. headquarters in Miami was "more aspirational than operational," a top bureau official said Friday, a day after seven Florida men were arrested on terrorism charges.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Andrea Zarate

articles.headline: Investors Are Looking on the Sunny Side of a Downturn
articles.snippet: Most investors — professionals and amateurs — have reacted with relative calm to the recent downdraft in global financial markets.
articles.abstract: Most investors — professionals and amateurs — have reacted with relative calm to the recent downdraft in global financial markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: As his investments in the stock markets of developing countries were hitting record highs in early May, Tristram Millard had a nagging feeling that things were about to turn down.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Sportonomics Beguiles 3 Economists
articles.snippet: The authors of "The Wages of Wins" are frank about their desire to have their book be seen as the "Freakonomics" of sports, but does it really matter whether Shaq is better than Kobe?
articles.abstract: The authors of "The Wages of Wins" are frank about their desire to have their book be seen as the "Freakonomics" of sports, but does it really matter whether Shaq is better than Kobe?
articles.lead_paragraph: SPORTS are entertainment. Sports do not often change our world; rather they serve as a distraction from our world."

articles.headline: Court Says S.E.C. Lacks Authority on Hedge Funds
articles.snippet: A federal appeals court ruled that the commission exceeded its power by treating investors in a hedge fund as "clients" of the fund manager.
articles.abstract: A federal appeals court ruled that the commission exceeded its power by treating investors in a hedge fund as "clients" of the fund manager.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission lacks the authority to regulate hedge funds, dealing a possibly fatal blow to the commission's efforts to oversee a rapidly growing industry that now has $1.1 trillion in assets.

articles.headline: Fear Invades a Once-Comfortable Iraqi Enclave
articles.snippet: Mansour is Baghdad's Upper East Side, but it is no longer address everyone wants; insurgents have come to Mansour in past two months to gun down city councilman, kidnap four Russian Embassy workers, shoot tailor dead in his shop and bomb pastry sh...
articles.abstract: Mansour is Baghdad's Upper East Side, but it is no longer address everyone wants; insurgents have come to Mansour in past two months to gun down city councilman, kidnap four Russian Embassy workers, shoot tailor dead in his shop and bomb pastry shop; Mansour, religiously mixed area just three miles from fortified Green Zone, feels more like wartime Beirut than Park Avenue, and its affluent residents worry that wave of violence that has devoured large swaths of Baghdad has begun encroaching on them; map; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 23 - Mansour is Baghdad's Upper East Side. It has fancy pastry shops, jewelry stores, a designer furniture boutique and an elite social club.

articles.headline: Market Forces Pushing Doctors to Be More Available
articles.snippet: Article on growing number of physicians who have streamlined their schedules, added Internet services and taken other steps to better meet needs of their patients as competition from walk-in medical offices and retail-store clinics increases; Amer...
articles.abstract: Article on growing number of physicians who have streamlined their schedules, added Internet services and taken other steps to better meet needs of their patients as competition from walk-in medical offices and retail-store clinics increases; American Academy of Family Physicians is spending $8 million on consultants who visit doctors nationwide to suggest improvements to patient care; American College of Physicians is promoting 'patient-centric' care; changes at office of Dr Melissa Gerdes in Whitehouse, Tex, described; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Alice Kissell, 58, a longtime asthma patient, still gets indignant when she recalls the brusque receptionists and hours of waiting to see a doctor at her former health maintenance organization in Southern California.

articles.headline: Anadarko to Pay $21 Billion for 2 Rivals
articles.snippet: Anadarko Petroleum, in move that would create one of US's largest independent oil companies, agrees to buy Kerr-McGee for $16.4 billion and Western Gas Resources for $4.7 billion to expand its operations into Gulf of Mexico and Rocky Mountains; ph...
articles.abstract: Anadarko Petroleum, in move that would create one of US's largest independent oil companies, agrees to buy Kerr-McGee for $16.4 billion and Western Gas Resources for $4.7 billion to expand its operations into Gulf of Mexico and Rocky Mountains; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: In a move that will create one of the nation's largest independent oil companies, Anadarko Petroleum said yesterday that it had agreed to buy two smaller rivals for $21.1 billion in cash to expand its operations into North America's fastest-growing oil and gas regions.

articles.headline: Sportonomics Beguiles 3 Economists
articles.snippet: Joe Nocera column on new book The Wages of Wins: Taking Measure of the Many Myths of Modern Sports by economists David Berri of California State University, Martin Schmidt of College of William and Mary and Stacey Brook of University of Sioux Fall...
articles.abstract: Joe Nocera column on new book The Wages of Wins: Taking Measure of the Many Myths of Modern Sports by economists David Berri of California State University, Martin Schmidt of College of William and Mary and Stacey Brook of University of Sioux Falls; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: SPORTS are entertainment. Sports do not often change our world; rather they serve as a distraction from our world."

articles.headline: F.B.I. Killed Plot in Talking Stage, a Top Aide Says
articles.snippet: FBI Deputy Dir John S Pistole, day after seven Florida men were arrested on terrorism charges, says plot to topple Sears Tower in Chicago and attack FBI headquarters in Miami was more aspirational than operational; Atty Gen Alberto R Gonzales says...
articles.abstract: FBI Deputy Dir John S Pistole, day after seven Florida men were arrested on terrorism charges, says plot to topple Sears Tower in Chicago and attack FBI headquarters in Miami was more aspirational than operational; Atty Gen Alberto R Gonzales says authorities chose to head off would-be plot when it was at discussion stage; says men posed no immediate threat; authorities identify Narseal Batiste as ringleader of group, and other suspects as Burson Augustin, Rothschild Augustine, Naudimar Herrera, Stanley G Phanor, Patrick Abraham and Lyglenson Lemorin; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23 - A plot to topple the Sears Tower in Chicago and attack the F.B.I. headquarters in Miami was "more aspirational than operational," a top bureau official said Friday, a day after seven Florida men were arrested on terrorism charges.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Andrea Zarate

articles.headline: Cheney Assails Press on Report on Bank Data
articles.snippet: Vice Pres Dick Cheney defends secret program that examines banking records of Americans and others in vast international database, and criticizes news media for disclosing operation he says is legal and essential to fighting terrorism; financial t...
articles.abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney defends secret program that examines banking records of Americans and others in vast international database, and criticizes news media for disclosing operation he says is legal and essential to fighting terrorism; financial tracking program was disclosed by New York Times and other news organizations; US officials have expressed concerns that Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication (Swift), Brussels banking consortium that provides access to database, might withdraw from program if its role were disclosed; program is run out of CIA and overseen by Treasury Dept; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 23 - Vice President Dick Cheney on Friday vigorously defended a secret program that examines banking records of Americans and others in a vast international database, and harshly criticized the news media for disclosing an operation he said was legal and "absolutely essential" to fighting terrorism.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Investors Are Looking on the Sunny Side of a Downturn
articles.snippet: Article on investor reaction to downdraft in global financial markets; says most individual investors reportedly are making only minor adjustments to their portfolios and transfer activity in 401(k) accounts has increased only slightly--mostly out...
articles.abstract: Article on investor reaction to downdraft in global financial markets; says most individual investors reportedly are making only minor adjustments to their portfolios and transfer activity in 401(k) accounts has increased only slightly--mostly out of emerging market funds; photos; graphs (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: As his investments in the stock markets of developing countries were hitting record highs in early May, Tristram Millard had a nagging feeling that things were about to turn down.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Court Says S.E.C. Lacks Authority on Hedge Funds
articles.snippet: US appeals court rules that Securities and Exchange Commission lacks authority to regulate hedge funds, dealing possibly fatal blow to commission's efforts to oversee growing industry that has $1.1 trillion in assets; rules that commission exceede...
articles.abstract: US appeals court rules that Securities and Exchange Commission lacks authority to regulate hedge funds, dealing possibly fatal blow to commission's efforts to oversee growing industry that has $1.1 trillion in assets; rules that commission exceeded its power by treating investors in hedge fund as clients of fund manager; ruling means that Congressional action would be required to grant SEC authority to force hedge fund managers to register, or for commission to impose other rules on such funds; SEC Chmn Christopher Cox comments; his photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission lacks the authority to regulate hedge funds, dealing a possibly fatal blow to the commission's efforts to oversee a rapidly growing industry that now has $1.1 trillion in assets.

articles.headline: U.S. General in Iraq Outlines Troop Cuts
articles.snippet: His plan projects sharp reductions in the U.S. military presence in Iraq by the end of 2007, with the first cuts coming this September.
articles.abstract: His plan projects sharp reductions in the U.S. military presence in Iraq by the end of 2007, with the first cuts coming this September.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 24 — The top American commander in Iraq has drafted a plan that projects sharp reductions in the United States military presence there by the end of 2007, with the first cuts coming this September, American officials say.

articles.headline: Buffett's Baby Is Taking a Bumpy Ride
articles.snippet: Warren E. Buffett's NetJets company, which peddles fractional ownerships in private jets, has endured a bumpy financial ride.
articles.abstract: Warren E. Buffett's NetJets company, which peddles fractional ownerships in private jets, has endured a bumpy financial ride.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHOWING on salads and sipping San Pellegrino water at the Santa Monica, Calif., airport two weeks ago, a well-heeled group of travelers compared notes on a fleet of spiffy Hawkers, Gulfstreams and Citations that NetJets, which peddles fractional ownerships in private jets, had assembled for their inspection.

articles.headline: Soviet-Style Proxies, Made in the U.S.A.
articles.snippet: A recent ruling makes it seem that the S.E.C. wants shareholders to be stuck in a Soviet-style regime as far as director elections are concerned.
articles.abstract: A recent ruling makes it seem that the S.E.C. wants shareholders to be stuck in a Soviet-style regime as far as director elections are concerned.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT'S hard to believe that the Securities and Exchange Commission wants United States shareholders to be stuck in a Soviet-style regime as far as director elections are concerned. But the commission's ruling last week on a proxy proposal put forward by a shareholder of CA Inc. sure makes it seem that way.

articles.headline: Boom in Ethanol Reshapes Economy of Heartland
articles.snippet: Small towns are becoming flashpoints in the ethanol bonanza that is reshaping rural America's economic base.
articles.abstract: Small towns are becoming flashpoints in the ethanol bonanza that is reshaping rural America's economic base.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Wary of U.S., Syria and Iran Strengthen Ties
articles.snippet: The two governments are tightening relations on several fronts as power shifts away from the Sunni to Shiites.
articles.abstract: The two governments are tightening relations on several fronts as power shifts away from the Sunni to Shiites.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAYEDA ZEINAB, Syria, June 24 — For a long time, the top-selling poster in Hassan al-Sheikh's gift shop here showed President Bashar al-Assad of Syria seated beside the leader of Hezbollah in Lebanon. A few weeks ago a slightly different poster overtook it, this one with the Syrian president, the Hezbollah leader and Iran's president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

articles.headline: The Winding Road to Grasso's Huge Payday
articles.snippet: An examination of Richard A. Grasso's payout shines a light on flawed governance practices and clashing egos at the New York Stock Exchange.
articles.abstract: An examination of Richard A. Grasso's payout shines a light on flawed governance practices and clashing egos at the New York Stock Exchange.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the spring of 2003, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, Richard A. Grasso, had his eyes on a very rich prize. Although Mr. Grasso's annual compensation at the time was about $12 million, on a par with the salaries of Wall Street titans whose companies the exchange helped regulate, he had accumulated $140 million in pension savings that he wanted to cash in — while still staying on the job.

articles.headline: The Winding Road to Grasso's Huge Payday
articles.snippet: Article examines scandal involving former New York Stock Exchange chairman and chief executive Richard Grasso and $140 million lump sum pension savings he sought to cash in 2003 while still in post; focuses on role of Goldman Sachs chairman Henry ...
articles.abstract: Article examines scandal involving former New York Stock Exchange chairman and chief executive Richard Grasso and $140 million lump sum pension savings he sought to cash in 2003 while still in post; focuses on role of Goldman Sachs chairman Henry Paulson Jr, member of exchange's compensation committee, and Martin Lipton, board's chief counsel on governance matters; suit filed against Grasso by New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer is about to go to trial; photos; graph (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Cleaning Up, or at Least Hoping To
articles.snippet: Eldwyn Brown, owner of coin-operated laundromat in Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, may have his first profitable year since opening in reviving commercial district; Brown has advantage over many other entrepreneurs, as he did not have to r...
articles.abstract: Eldwyn Brown, owner of coin-operated laundromat in Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, may have his first profitable year since opening in reviving commercial district; Brown has advantage over many other entrepreneurs, as he did not have to rely on business as sole source of income; he kept his job as systems analyst for two years after opening business and left with buyout after 18 years with company; he also works as consultant and owns property, all of which helped him secure startup loan; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BACK in 2000, 49,309 business establishments opened in New York State, according to the federal government's count. Nobody knows how many are still operating, but Eldwyn Brown's coin-operated Laundromat is among those that are.

articles.headline: Buffett's Baby Is Taking a Bumpy Ride
articles.snippet: Article on bumpy financial ride that NetJets, private jet fractional ownership company that Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway bought from Richard Santulli in 1998, has endured; says company lost $80 million last year after making $10 million pro...
articles.abstract: Article on bumpy financial ride that NetJets, private jet fractional ownership company that Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway bought from Richard Santulli in 1998, has endured; says company lost $80 million last year after making $10 million profit in 2004 despite boom in demand for part-time jets; ; chairman and chief executive Santulli comments on problems but is optimistic about future; some analysts and shareholders voice concerns about NetJet's ability to turn itself around; photos; graphs (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: CHOWING on salads and sipping San Pellegrino water at the Santa Monica, Calif., airport two weeks ago, a well-heeled group of travelers compared notes on a fleet of spiffy Hawkers, Gulfstreams and Citations that NetJets, which peddles fractional ownerships in private jets, had assembled for their inspection.

articles.headline: Wary of U.S., Syria and Iran Strengthen Ties
articles.snippet: Governments and people of Iran and Syria are tightening relations on several fronts as regional power shifts away from once-dominant Sunnis to Shiites and United States seeks to contain Iran and isolate Syria; fear that US may soon negotiate deal ...
articles.abstract: Governments and people of Iran and Syria are tightening relations on several fronts as regional power shifts away from once-dominant Sunnis to Shiites and United States seeks to contain Iran and isolate Syria; fear that US may soon negotiate deal with Iran over Iraq and nuclear weapons is causing Arab governments once hostile to Iran to soften their public posture; Syria has inflated its power by subtle double game and setting itself up as possible go-between; photo (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: SAYEDA ZEINAB, Syria, June 24 - For a long time, the top-selling poster in Hassan al-Sheikh's gift shop here showed President Bashar al-Assad of Syria seated beside the leader of Hezbollah in Lebanon. A few weeks ago a slightly different poster overtook it, this one with the Syrian president, the Hezbollah leader and Iran's president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

articles.headline: Soviet-Style Proxies, Made in the U.S.A.
articles.snippet: Gretchen Morgenson column on Securities and Exchange Commission ruling that CA Inc can exclude from proxy statement shareholder proposal from Amalgamated Bank's LongView Collective Investment fund to keep or oust directors Alfonse D'Amato and Lewi...
articles.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on Securities and Exchange Commission ruling that CA Inc can exclude from proxy statement shareholder proposal from Amalgamated Bank's LongView Collective Investment fund to keep or oust directors Alfonse D'Amato and Lewis Ranieri; from proxy statement (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: IT'S hard to believe that the Securities and Exchange Commission wants United States shareholders to be stuck in a Soviet-style regime as far as director elections are concerned. But the commission's ruling last week on a proxy proposal put forward by a shareholder of CA Inc. sure makes it seem that way.

articles.headline: TOP U.S. GENERAL IN IRAQ OUTLINES SHARP TROOP CUT
articles.snippet: Top American commander in Iraq Gen George W Casey has drafted plan for number of American combat brigades in Iraq to decrease to five or six from current level of 14 brigades by December 2007, with first cuts coming this September; other kinds of ...
articles.abstract: Top American commander in Iraq Gen George W Casey has drafted plan for number of American combat brigades in Iraq to decrease to five or six from current level of 14 brigades by December 2007, with first cuts coming this September; other kinds of units will not be withdrawn as quickly; American officials emphasize that withdrawals will depend on continued progress, including development of competent Iraqi security forces; Casey has not presented formal plan for Pres Bush's approval but rather concept of how US might move forward after consulting with Iraqi authorities; photo (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 24 - The top American commander in Iraq has drafted a plan that projects sharp reductions in the United States military presence there by the end of 2007, with the first cuts coming this September, American officials say.

articles.headline: Bush's Immigration Plan Stalled As House G.O.P. Grew Anxious
articles.snippet: Sidelining of Pres Bush's overhaul of immigration laws by House Republicans amounts to clear rebuke of Bush on issue he has made his signature domestic policy initiative of year; administration was overly optimistic in assessment of prospects for ...
articles.abstract: Sidelining of Pres Bush's overhaul of immigration laws by House Republicans amounts to clear rebuke of Bush on issue he has made his signature domestic policy initiative of year; administration was overly optimistic in assessment of prospects for building bipartisan coalition in support of bill and misread depth of Republican hostility to bill; House bill would threaten Republicans' ability to broaden their appeal for Hispanic voters, but House Republicans fear angering voters who see Bush's plan as amnesty; photo (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 24 - For the White House, the Congressional picnic last week seemed like the perfect setting to mend strained relations with Republican allies on Capitol Hill: President Bush and his advisers eating taquitos and Mexican confetti rice on the lawn of the White House with Republican Congressional leaders.
articles.byline: This article is by Adam Nagourney, Carl Hulse and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Boom in Ethanol Reshapes Economy of Heartland
articles.snippet: Article in series The Energy Challenge; boom in ethanol production is being driven by generous government subsidies, surging demand for gasoline supplement, politics and desire for profit, despite concerns that large-scale diversion of agricultura...
articles.abstract: Article in series The Energy Challenge; boom in ethanol production is being driven by generous government subsidies, surging demand for gasoline supplement, politics and desire for profit, despite concerns that large-scale diversion of agricultural resources to fuel could result in price increase in food for people and livestock; at least 39 new ethanol plants are expected to be completed within next year despite continuing doubts about whether fuel provides genuine energy savings; photo; map; graphs (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: This article was reported by Alexei Barrionuevo, Simon Romero and Michael Janofsky and Written By Mr. Barrionuevo

articles.headline: Militants' Raid on Israel Raises Gaza Tension
articles.snippet: Israel threatened a harsh response to a raid by Palestinian militants in which two soldiers were killed and one kidnapped.
articles.abstract: Israel threatened a harsh response to a raid by Palestinian militants in which two soldiers were killed and one kidnapped.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Amid Iraqi Chaos, Schools Fill After Long Decline
articles.snippet: Enrollment in Iraqi schools has risen every year since the U.S. invasion, reversing more than a decade of declines.
articles.abstract: Enrollment in Iraqi schools has risen every year since the U.S. invasion, reversing more than a decade of declines.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 25 — Enrollment in Iraqi schools has risen every year since the American invasion, according to Iraqi government figures, reversing more than a decade of declines and offering evidence of increased prosperity for some Iraqis.

articles.headline: At CNN, News That Plays to the Ratings
articles.snippet: After dumping "Crossfire" last year, CNN's plan to eschew an agenda and focus on straight reporting has been beaten back by the brutal competition in cable news.
articles.abstract: After dumping "Crossfire" last year, CNN's plan to eschew an agenda and focus on straight reporting has been beaten back by the brutal competition in cable news.
articles.lead_paragraph: "The news is the star."

articles.headline: Inquiry Clouds Future for a Hedge Fund Survivor
articles.snippet: Arthur J. Samberg is a hedge fund survivor,  but he is facing his biggest challenge yet  an S.E.C. inquiry into possible insider trading.
articles.abstract: Arthur J. Samberg is a hedge fund survivor,  but he is facing his biggest challenge yet  an S.E.C. inquiry into possible insider trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the world of hedge funds, where timing seems to be everything, Arthur J. Samberg is a survivor. He and a partner went into business in 1986, only to lose much of their money in the 1987 stock market crash.

articles.headline: Buffett to Give Bulk of His Fortune to Gates Charity
articles.snippet: Warren E. Buffett's gift of about $37.4 billion vaults him into the top tier of charitable giving.
articles.abstract: Warren E. Buffett's gift of about $37.4 billion vaults him into the top tier of charitable giving.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Timothy L. O'Brien and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: Tax Revenues Are a Windfall for Louisiana
articles.snippet: The state predicted that collections would plunge after last year's hurricanes, but instead revenue is setting a record.
articles.abstract: The state predicted that collections would plunge after last year's hurricanes, but instead revenue is setting a record.
articles.lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — State officials assumed that Louisiana's tax base had been battered by last year's hurricanes, but the latest figures show that the opposite occurred: more tax dollars than ever are pouring into the state's coffers as the budget year draws to an end.

articles.headline: The 40-Year-Old Virgin Executive
articles.snippet: Dan Abrams, in his first management post, is the new day-to-day boss of MSNBC, only the first of many changes coming to the network.
articles.abstract: Dan Abrams, in his first management post, is the new day-to-day boss of MSNBC, only the first of many changes coming to the network.
articles.lead_paragraph: If NBC's selection of Dan Abrams, an on-air anchor, as the new day-to-day boss of MSNBC left employees of that all-news cable channel gasping in shock — and it did — the next steps in the reshaping of the long-struggling network are likely to generate at least a few low whistles of surprise.

articles.headline: Arcelor Deal With Mittal Establishes Steel Giant
articles.snippet: The world's two largest steel companies have agreed to merge in a deal valued at more than $33.5 billion.
articles.abstract: The world's two largest steel companies have agreed to merge in a deal valued at more than $33.5 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 25 — After a bitter battle, Arcelor agreed on Sunday to a merger valued at 26.8 billion euros, or about $33.53 billion, with a rival, Mittal Steel, creating a new steel giant.
articles.byline: By Heather Timmons and Anand Giridharadas

articles.headline: What if They Built an Urban Wireless Network and Hardly Anyone Used It?
articles.snippet: Ninety percent of those in Taipei, Taiwan, can access its wireless network, but just 40,000 of 2.6 million residents pay to use it.
articles.abstract: Ninety percent of those in Taipei, Taiwan, can access its wireless network, but just 40,000 of 2.6 million residents pay to use it.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Peter Shyu, an engineer, spends most of his day out of the office, and when he needs an Internet connection he often pops into one of the many coffee shops in this city that offer free wireless access.

articles.headline: Arcelor Deal With Mittal Establishes Steel Giant
articles.snippet: After a bitter battle, Arcelor agreed on Sunday to a merger valued at 26.8 billion euros, or about $33.53 billion, with a rival, Mittal Steel, creating a new steel giant.     The deal would combine Arcelor -- a symbol of successful, pan-European c...
articles.abstract: After a bitter battle, Arcelor agreed on Sunday to a merger valued at 26.8 billion euros, or about $33.53 billion, with a rival, Mittal Steel, creating a new steel giant.     The deal would combine Arcelor -- a symbol of successful, pan-European cooperation and economic revival, with operations that span Belgium, France, Luxembourg and Spain -- with a fast-growing conglomerate founded by the India-born Lakshmi Mittal. He built a fortune turning around troubled steel plants in expanding markets from Trinidad to Kazakhstan.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 25 - After a bitter battle, Arcelor agreed on Sunday to a merger valued at 26.8 billion euros, or about $33.53 billion, with a rival, Mittal Steel, creating a new steel giant.
articles.byline: By Heather Timmons and Anand Giridharadas

articles.headline: In Texas, Fighting to Keep Brahms on Air
articles.snippet: In this landscape of oil derricks and Rangerettes -- a renowned drill team dressed in smiles and miniskirts -- a tiny radio station sends out a lifeline to classical music lovers in East Texas.      It is KTPB, the station of Kilgore College, whic...
articles.abstract: In this landscape of oil derricks and Rangerettes -- a renowned drill team dressed in smiles and miniskirts -- a tiny radio station sends out a lifeline to classical music lovers in East Texas.      It is KTPB, the station of Kilgore College, which educates the children of oil hands and other blue-collar workers. Now the college has decided it can no longer afford to support the station and has announced its sale. The new owner? A Christian-music broadcasting company from California, which will pay the college $2.46 million over 10 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: KILGORE, Tex., June 24 - In this landscape of oil derricks and Rangerettes -- a renowned drill team dressed in smiles and miniskirts -- a tiny radio station sends out a lifeline to classical music lovers in East Texas.

articles.headline: Buffett to Give Bulk of His Fortune to Gates Charity
articles.snippet: Warren E. Buffett, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and one of the world's wealthiest men, plans to donate the bulk of his $44 billion fortune to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and four other philanthropies starting in July.     The do...
articles.abstract: Warren E. Buffett, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and one of the world's wealthiest men, plans to donate the bulk of his $44 billion fortune to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and four other philanthropies starting in July.     The donations, outlined in a series of letters that Mr. Buffett released yesterday and will execute today, represent a singular and historic act of charitable giving that vaults him into the top tier of industrialists and entrepreneurs like Andrew Carnegie, John D. Rockefeller Sr., Henry Ford, J. Paul Getty, W. K. Kellogg and Mr. Gates himself, all men whose fortunes have endowed some of the world's richest private foundations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Timothy L. O'Brien and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: What if They Built an Urban Wireless Network and Hardly Anyone Used It?
articles.snippet: Peter Shyu, an engineer, spends most of his day out of the office, and when he needs an Internet connection he often pops into one of the many coffee shops in this city that offer free wireless access.      He could use WiFly, the extensive wirele...
articles.abstract: Peter Shyu, an engineer, spends most of his day out of the office, and when he needs an Internet connection he often pops into one of the many coffee shops in this city that offer free wireless access.      He could use WiFly, the extensive wireless network commissioned by the city government that is the cornerstone of Taipei's ambitious plan to turn itself into an international technology hub. But that would cost him $12.50 a month.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan - Peter Shyu, an engineer, spends most of his day out of the office, and when he needs an Internet connection he often pops into one of the many coffee shops in this city that offer free wireless access.

articles.headline: The 40-Year-Old Virgin Executive
articles.snippet: If NBC's selection of Dan Abrams, an on-air anchor, as the new day-to-day boss of MSNBC left employees of that all-news cable channel gasping in shock -- and it did -- the next steps in the reshaping of the long-struggling network are likely to ge...
articles.abstract: If NBC's selection of Dan Abrams, an on-air anchor, as the new day-to-day boss of MSNBC left employees of that all-news cable channel gasping in shock -- and it did -- the next steps in the reshaping of the long-struggling network are likely to generate at least a few low whistles of surprise.     Mr. Abrams, in an interview at the MSNBC headquarters in Secaucus, N.J., acknowledged that he was still in the learning stages of his new job. At the age of 40, he's taking his first management post in television, where he has worked as a legal analyst and news anchor. While steering away from suggestions that a widespread overhaul of MSNBC is imminent, he did suggest that he would push right away for more breaking news coverage during the channel's daytime hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: If NBC's selection of Dan Abrams, an on-air anchor, as the new day-to-day boss of MSNBC left employees of that all-news cable channel gasping in shock -- and it did -- the next steps in the reshaping of the long-struggling network are likely to generate at least a few low whistles of surprise.

articles.headline: Tax Revenues Are a Windfall for Louisiana
articles.snippet: State officials assumed that Louisiana's tax base had been battered by last year's hurricanes, but the latest figures show that the opposite occurred: more tax dollars than ever are pouring into the state's coffers as the budget year draws to an e...
articles.abstract: State officials assumed that Louisiana's tax base had been battered by last year's hurricanes, but the latest figures show that the opposite occurred: more tax dollars than ever are pouring into the state's coffers as the budget year draws to an end.     The state predicted that tax collections would plunge by almost $900 million this year, and it slashed spending to match. Instead, a record $9.2 billion is on track to be collected by the time the budget year ends on June 30, and at least some of that tax flow looks as if it is likely to continue.
articles.lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. - State officials assumed that Louisiana's tax base had been battered by last year's hurricanes, but the latest figures show that the opposite occurred: more tax dollars than ever are pouring into the state's coffers as the budget year draws to an end.

articles.headline: At CNN, News That Plays to the Ratings
articles.snippet: ''The news is the star.''  -- Ted Turner, founder of CNN         AFTER dumping the yelling heads of ''Crossfire'' at the beginning of last year, Jonathan Klein, president of CNN's domestic operations, said that the original cable news network was ...
articles.abstract: ''The news is the star.''  -- Ted Turner, founder of CNN         AFTER dumping the yelling heads of ''Crossfire'' at the beginning of last year, Jonathan Klein, president of CNN's domestic operations, said that the original cable news network was doubling down on straight reporting.      ''We are not about fomenting an agenda,'' he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: "The news is the star." -- Ted Turner, founder of CNN

articles.headline: Inquiry Clouds Future for a Hedge Fund Survivor
articles.snippet: In the world of hedge funds, where timing seems to be everything, Arthur J. Samberg is a survivor. He and a partner went into business in 1986, only to lose much of their money in the 1987 stock market crash.     He survived that, though, and unti...
articles.abstract: In the world of hedge funds, where timing seems to be everything, Arthur J. Samberg is a survivor. He and a partner went into business in 1986, only to lose much of their money in the 1987 stock market crash.     He survived that, though, and until recently his timing has been far better. In the technology boom of the 1990's, the fund not only recovered, but soared. Amassing $15 billion in assets, Pequot Capital Management became one of the largest hedge funds. It made its partners and investors wealthy, and became a darling of Wall Street firms for the huge commissions they earned buying and selling securities for Pequot.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the world of hedge funds, where timing seems to be everything, Arthur J. Samberg is a survivor. He and a partner went into business in 1986, only to lose much of their money in the 1987 stock market crash.

articles.headline: Militants' Raid on Israel Raises Gaza Tension
articles.snippet: In an ominous development, Israel threatened strong military action on Sunday after eight Palestinian militants in Gaza, including members of the governing faction Hamas, emerged from a secret tunnel dug 300 yards into Israel, killed two soldiers,...
articles.abstract: In an ominous development, Israel threatened strong military action on Sunday after eight Palestinian militants in Gaza, including members of the governing faction Hamas, emerged from a secret tunnel dug 300 yards into Israel, killed two soldiers, wounded three and kidnapped another.      Two of the Palestinians were killed but the rest escaped into Gaza with the captive Israeli soldier, Cpl. Gilad Shalit, 19, who is believed to have been wounded. He was the first Israeli soldier kidnapped in more than a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
